coredata.dc:title: EXAFS and x-ray diffraction study of a mixed NiCl2CoCl2 solution
coredata.dc:creator: Corrias, A.
Musinu, A.
Pinna, G.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A mixed solution of CoCl2 and NiCl2 (with concentration of each cation equal to 0.5 M) enriched in Cl− up to a Cl−/cation atomic ratio of 7, has been examined by X-ray diffraction and EXAFS spectroscopy. The global information about the interactions of the two transition metals obtained by X-ray diffraction is in agreement with results obtained independently by EXAFS for cobalt and nickel. A stronger tendency of the Co2+ ion with respect to Ni2+ to form chloro complexes is seen by EXAFS.

Introduction The formation of metal complexes in aqueous chloride solutions plays an important role in hydrometallurgy [1 ] _ In fact, the efficiency of separation processes for metal recovery from chloride solutions of waste materials through techniques of solvent or liquidliquid extraction is probably connected with the different tendencies of the metals to form chloro-complexes. The structural investigations about complex formation phenomena published so far [2-71 generally deal with systems characterized by chemico-physical conditions far from those typical of the separation processes, primarily because they contain only one metal at a time. One mixed solution has been examined [8] a solution of CdC12 and ZnC12 was investigated by Xray diffraction (XRD) in a situation that, given the limitations of the technique used, was as close as possible to the conditions in which the separation process could take place. In this particular case the possibility of evaluating simultaneously the average degree of Zn and Cd complexation was evidenced. Unfortunately, the use of XØ on mixed solutions is restricted to cases in which the ionic radii of the metals and their scattering factors are so different that X-ray diffraction can discriminate. This is the case with the Zn-Cd pair [8] , as well as with the Ca-Mg pair examined in a previous investigation [9] where the system was simpler, as only water molecules could be nearest-neighbours to the cations. 0 009-2614/85/$ 03.30 © Elsevier Science Publishers B_V_ (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) On the other hand, the aforementioned favourable conditions do not exist for the pair Co-Ni; separate solutions of COC12 [4,5] and NiC12 [6) have been examined by XRD in various concentrations and Cl-/ Me'-+ ratios. Each system showed some degree of chloro complexation which increased as the Cl-/Me2+ ratio- Looking for an investigative tool that would allow the study of a complex system in which Co2* and Ni2+ ions are present, we ended up with the idea of using EXAFS spectroscopy- In fact, it is known [10] that in principle this technique can give independent information on the interactions of different ions in the same solution. However, the quality of the results obtainable has to be tested case by case, as it depends on how far the experimental conditions are from the optimal ones. In this respect, the upper limit of the experimental data may be too low; in our situation, the energy range that can be explored in the case of cobalt is limited to about 600eV (separation of Co andNiK-edges). While this value should be sufficient to give the information sought, it may be much reduced by noise or distortions (due to inadequate data treatment) that are generally mainly reflected in the high-energy portion of the experimental data; a low limit, in turn, leads to insufficient resolution of the radial function obtainable (cut-off error in the Fourier transform) and, thus to a poor determination of the structural parameters describing the system. The aim of this work is also to verify that this critical condition still yields reliable results. 295 Volume 120, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 October 1985 As a first approach, EXAFS spectroscopy was applied to solutions containing Ni2+ ions and increasing Cl-/Ni2+ ratios [7], giving results that, on the whole, confirmed the XRD ones [6). A mixed solution of COC12 and NiC12 was examined; the concentration of the two metal ions was the same (0.5 M), and the solution was enriched in Clions by a suitable addition of LiCl up to a ratio Cl-/ Me2+ = 7 (Me2+ being the total amount of the divalent metals). The same solution was also studied by XRD, in order to check the results obtained. In fact, as will be described in greater detail later, XRD gave distances and coordination numbers of the interactions Met+-H20 and Met+-Cl-, that is, information on the mean coordination of the metal ions in the system. This global result should be consistent with those obtained independently by EXAFS on C02+ and Ni2-- [11]. 2. XRD results The experimental X-ray apparatus and data collection procedures have been described elsewhere [12,13]_ Diffraction data underwent the usual corrections (background, polarization, absorption) and were normalized by standard procedures. From the structure function i(s) thus obtained (s = 4a sin t9/W, where t9 is half the scattering angle and h is the wavelength of the X-ray) the total correlation function G(r) was obtained via the Fourier transform [13].In fig. 1 the experimental radial curve of this mixed solution is compared with the G(r) previously calculated [5] in the case of a 1 M COC12 solution, this too enriched in CI- by addition of LiCl so that the same value of 7 was obtained for the Cl-/Me2+ ratio. In detail, two prominent peaks appear; the first one, at about 2.10 A, is undoubtedly due to C02+-H20 and Nit +-H20 correlations, which, as already mentioned, are indistinguishable in XRD. Conclusions In general, the results obtained by EXAFS are in agreement with those provided by XRD. The average number of chloro-metal interactions calculated from XRD data comes out a little higher than the one obtained from EXAFS when the assumption of only water molecules around the Ni2+ ion is accepted (0.81 against 0.61); on the other hand, if the choice of the two-shell model is preferred for both Co2+ and Ni2'1 ions, the result is reversed (0.81 against 0.95)_ These figures give a rough evaluation of the confidence limits within which the "true" result must fall; for this reason, the standard errors calculated by the least-squares fitting program for each of the parameters given in the tables are considered meaningless. XRD and EXAFS results support each other as far as the presence of Met+-Cl- contacts is concerned- In particular, EXAFS gives evidence of a stronger tendency of the C02+ ion with respect to Ni2+ to form chloro-complexes. The sensitivity of the EXAFS method appears to be good in this case and quite promising for more systematic investigations. References [1 ] G_M.
